content: quote: WASHINGTON -- President Barack Obama signed a $410 billion spending bill Wednesday that includes thousands of pet projects inserted by lawmakers, even as he unveiled new rules to restrict such so-called earmarks. At the same time, after Democrats criticized former President George W. Bush's signing statements, Mr. Obama issued one of his own, declaring five provisions in the spending bill to be unconstitutional and nonbinding, including one aimed at preventing punishment of whistleblowers. <more> "http://online.wsj.com/article/SB123680763049200481.html" Why didn't he veto the bill if it contained 5 unconstitutional provisions ... not to mention all that pork?
quote: WASHINGTON -- President Barack Obama signed a $410 billion spending bill Wednesday that includes thousands of pet projects inserted by lawmakers, even as he unveiled new rules to restrict such so-called earmarks. At the same time, after Democrats criticized former President George W. Bush's signing statements, Mr. Obama issued one of his own, declaring five provisions in the spending bill to be unconstitutional and nonbinding, including one aimed at preventing punishment of whistleblowers. <more> "http://online.wsj.com/article/SB123680763049200481.html"
reply: Why didn't he veto the bill if it contained 5 unconstitutional provisions ... not to mention all that pork?
title: But ... but ... but ... I thought signing statements were BAD

title: But ... but ... but ... I thought signing statements were BAD

content: quote: Originally posted by I_M_Qwerty: quote: WASHINGTON -- President Barack Obama signed a $410 billion spending bill Wednesday that includes thousands of pet projects inserted by lawmakers, even as he unveiled new rules to restrict such so-called earmarks. At the same time, after Democrats criticized former President George W. Bush's signing statements, Mr. Obama issued one of his own, declaring five provisions in the spending bill to be unconstitutional and nonbinding, including one aimed at preventing punishment of whistleblowers. <more> "http://online.wsj.com/article/SB123680763049200481.html" Why didn't he veto the bill if it contained 5 unconstitutional provisions ... not to mention all that pork? If President Obama had vetoed the omnibus spending bill – that has been negotiated by both parties since last October, and includes almost 4,000 Republican earmarks - it would tie up Congress for months. Negotiating a new spending bill would take away from the actions needed to address the financial crisis that faces America today. It is a bad bill, but revisiting old business will not move the country forward. President Obama’s real test will come with the next budget, due before October 2009. If you joined John McCain to protest against the out of control spending of the Republican majority Congress in the 2004 budget - and the lack of veto by the Republican president, then ***** away at President Obama, even though he is doing the politically smart thing. If not, you are doing the stupid looking double standard dance. “Ten years ago, in 1994, Republicans won control of both Houses of Congress. For one brief shining moment, we employed true fiscal restraint and eventually managed to balance the budget and even attain that which had seemed unattainable–a surplus! Now, at a time of national crisis, we have thrown caution to the wind and continue to spend, and spend, and spend - all the while cutting taxes. The perfect evidence of this is the number of Congressional earmarks found in the 13 annual appropriations bills. In 1994 there were 4,126 earmarks - this year there were 14,040 earmarks . Where are our priorities?” John McCain, May 2005
quote: Originally posted by I_M_Qwerty: quote: WASHINGTON -- President Barack Obama signed a $410 billion spending bill Wednesday that includes thousands of pet projects inserted by lawmakers, even as he unveiled new rules to restrict such so-called earmarks. At the same time, after Democrats criticized former President George W. Bush's signing statements, Mr. Obama issued one of his own, declaring five provisions in the spending bill to be unconstitutional and nonbinding, including one aimed at preventing punishment of whistleblowers. <more> "http://online.wsj.com/article/SB123680763049200481.html" Why didn't he veto the bill if it contained 5 unconstitutional provisions ... not to mention all that pork?

Negotiating a new spending bill would take away from the actions needed to address the financial crisis that faces America today. It is a bad bill, but revisiting old business will not move the country forward. President Obama’s real test will come with the next budget, due before October 2009. If you joined John McCain to protest against the out of control spending of the Republican majority Congress in the 2004 budget - and the lack of veto by the Republican president, then ***** away at President Obama, even though he is doing the politically smart thing. If not, you are doing the stupid looking double standard dance. “Ten years ago, in 1994, Republicans won control of both Houses of Congress. For one brief shining moment, we employed true fiscal restraint and eventually managed to balance the budget and even attain that which had seemed unattainable–a surplus! Now, at a time of national crisis, we have thrown caution to the wind and continue to spend, and spend, and spend - all the while cutting taxes. The perfect evidence of this is the number of Congressional earmarks found in the 13 annual appropriations bills. In 1994 there were 4,126 earmarks - this year there were 14,040 earmarks . Where are our priorities?” John McCain, May 2005
title: But ... but ... but ... I thought signing statements were BAD
But ... but ... but ... I thought signing statements were BAD

content: quote: Originally posted by I_M_Qwerty: quote: WASHINGTON -- President Barack Obama signed a $410 billion spending bill Wednesday that includes thousands of pet projects inserted by lawmakers, even as he unveiled new rules to restrict such so-called earmarks. At the same time, after Democrats criticized former President George W. Bush's signing statements, Mr. Obama issued one of his own, declaring five provisions in the spending bill to be unconstitutional and nonbinding, including one aimed at preventing punishment of whistleblowers. <more> "http://online.wsj.com/article/SB123680763049200481.html" Why didn't he veto the bill if it contained 5 unconstitutional provisions ... not to mention all that pork? Because the continuing budget resolution the government has been operating under, which Bush signed last fall, was due to expire at midnight tonight. Without a new budget to take its place the government would have ground to a halt at midnight tonight. The previous Congress (Republicans and Democrats) didn't want to make the hard budget choices in the midst of an election campaign so they just passed it off to the next Congress and President. If you think the economy looks shakey now, just think what shutting the federal government down for a few weeks at this critical point would do to it. Or perhaps you're one of the ones hoping for a catastrophic failure of the economy for whatever political advantage the GOP might possibly gain from it.

reply: Because the continuing budget resolution the government has been operating under, which Bush signed last fall, was due to expire at midnight tonight. Without a new budget to take its place the government would have ground to a halt at midnight tonight. The previous Congress (Republicans and Democrats) didn't want to make the hard budget choices in the midst of an election campaign so they just passed it off to the next Congress and President. If you think the economy looks shakey now, just think what shutting the federal government down for a few weeks at this critical point would do to it. Or perhaps you're one of the ones hoping for a catastrophic failure of the economy for whatever political advantage the GOP might possibly gain from it.

content: quote: Originally posted by xerello: If President Obama had vetoed the omnibus spending bill – that has been negotiated by both parties since last October, and includes almost 4,000 Republican earmarks - it would tie up Congress for months. OK. It's that 'pork guilt' exists throughout Congress regardless of political party. As far as tieing up Congress for months is BS. They could have passed a continuing resolution to keep the government running until the end of the fiscal year.[/B] Negotiating a new spending bill would take away from the actions needed to address the financial crisis that faces America today. It is a bad bill, but revisiting old business will not move the country forward. [B]Both of these statement are BS. It would have taken REAL LEADERSHIP FROM BOTH PARTIES to accomplish that. Unfortunately, that doesn't exist. The country would MOVE FORWARD more quickly if it didn't have to be concerned about future tax increased that loom just over the horizon.[/B] President Obama’s real test will come with the next budget, due before October 2009. If you joined John McCain to protest against the out of control spending of the Republican majority Congress in the 2004 budget - and the lack of veto by the Republican president, then ***** away at President Obama, even though he is doing the politically smart thing. If not, you are doing the stupid looking double standard dance. “Ten years ago, in 1994, Republicans won control of both Houses of Congress. For one brief shining moment, we employed true fiscal restraint and eventually managed to balance the budget and even attain that which had seemed unattainable–a surplus! Now, at a time of national crisis, we have thrown caution to the wind and continue to spend, and spend, and spend - all the while cutting taxes. The perfect evidence of this is the number of Congressional earmarks found in the 13 annual appropriations bills. In 1994 there were 4,126 earmarks - [b]this year there were 14,040 earmarks . Where are our priorities?” John McCain, May 2005 [B]Again, everyone is guilty and the answer to that is simple--it's called TERM LIMITS![/B] (QUOTE)At the same time, after Democrats criticized former President George W. Bush's signing statements, Mr. Obama issued one of his own, declaring five provisions in the spending bill to be unconstitutional and nonbinding, including one aimed at preventing punishment of whistleblowers.(QUOTE) [B]And, exactly what is this statement all about? Does it mean whistle blowers can now be punished?[/B] (QUOTE)"We have to keep the door open," House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D., Calif.) said this week.(Quote) [B]It's open pelosi--wide open waiting for your departure![/B]

Unfortunately, that doesn't exist. The country would MOVE FORWARD more quickly if it didn't have to be concerned about future tax increased that loom just over the horizon.[/B] President Obama’s real test will come with the next budget, due before October 2009. If not, you are doing the stupid looking double standard dance. “Ten years ago, in 1994, Republicans won control of both Houses of Congress. For one brief shining moment, we employed true fiscal restraint and eventually managed to balance the budget and even attain that which had seemed unattainable–a surplus! Now, at a time of national crisis, we have thrown caution to the wind and continue to spend, and spend, and spend - all the while cutting taxes. The perfect evidence of this is the number of Congressional earmarks found in the 13 annual appropriations bills. In 1994 there were 4,126 earmarks - [b]this year there were 14,040 earmarks . Where are our priorities?” John McCain, May 2005

content: quote: Originally posted by BPCR45_90: quote: Originally posted by I_M_Qwerty: quote: WASHINGTON -- President Barack Obama signed a $410 billion spending bill Wednesday that includes thousands of pet projects inserted by lawmakers, even as he unveiled new rules to restrict such so-called earmarks. At the same time, after Democrats criticized former President George W. Bush's signing statements, Mr. Obama issued one of his own, declaring five provisions in the spending bill to be unconstitutional and nonbinding, including one aimed at preventing punishment of whistleblowers. <more> "http://online.wsj.com/article/SB123680763049200481.html" Why didn't he veto the bill if it contained 5 unconstitutional provisions ... not to mention all that pork? Because the continuing budget resolution the government has been operating under, which Bush signed last fall, was due to expire at midnight tonight. Without a new budget to take its place the government would have ground to a halt at midnight tonight. The previous Congress (Republicans and Democrats) didn't want to make the hard budget choices in the midst of an election campaign so they just passed it off to the next Congress and President. If you think the economy looks shakey now, just think what shutting the federal government down for a few weeks at this critical point would do to it. Or perhaps you're one of the ones hoping for a catastrophic failure of the economy for whatever political advantage the GOP might possibly gain from it. Sorry but that is flat wrong. The continuing resolution (HR 2638) that Bush signed last year expired on 6 March ... the Democratic Congress passed HR 38 on 6 Mar, signed by President Obama on 6 Mar, extending the continuing resolution. It could just as easily have extended the continuing resolution through the end of this fiscal year as it did with the 2007 budget and much of the 2008 budget. As to this: quote: Or perhaps you're one of the ones hoping for a catastrophic failure of the economy for whatever political advantage the GOP might possibly gain from it. Perhaps you are full of crap.

The continuing resolution (HR 2638) that Bush signed last year expired on 6 March ... the Democratic Congress passed HR 38 on 6 Mar, signed by President Obama on 6 Mar, extending the continuing resolution. content: quote: If President Obama had vetoed the omnibus spending bill – that has been negotiated by both parties since last October, and includes almost 4,000 Republican earmarks - it would tie up Congress for months. Not at all ... another simple extension of the continuing resolution through the end of the year would have had bipartisan support, stripped out the pork, and eliminated the provisions that POTUS 44 has declared "non-binding" on Constitutional issues.
quote: If President Obama had vetoed the omnibus spending bill – that has been negotiated by both parties since last October, and includes almost 4,000 Republican earmarks - it would tie up Congress for months.
reply: Not at all ... another simple extension of the continuing resolution through the end of the year would have had bipartisan support, stripped out the pork, and eliminated the provisions that POTUS 44 has declared "non-binding" on Constitutional issues.
title: But ... but ... but ... I thought signing statements were BAD

content: quote: If you joined John McCain to protest against the out of control spending of the Republican majority Congress in the 2004 budget - and the lack of veto by the Republican president, then ***** away at President Obama, even though he is doing the politically smart thing. If not, you are doing the stupid looking double standard dance. If opposing earmarks, other pork, and deficit spending is the criteria for how one looks dancing, I should be on "Dancing with the Stars" ... and I have my stack of Congressional correspondence to back me up ... including the letters I sent before and after passage of the bill under discussion. You'll find my comments on my two senators ... and their votes on McCain's failed amendment to this bill ... in other threads on this board.

content: quote: Originally posted by jrnh5150: Perhaps the Obama haters overlooked something? No, can't be...IM swears she isn't an Obama hater and likes to point out OTHER people's partisanship at every turn. She just CAN'T be a partisan Obama hater!

title: But ... but ... but ... I thought signing statements were BAD

content: quote: Originally posted by SeaWitch1220: quote: Originally posted by jrnh5150: Perhaps the Obama haters overlooked something? No, can't be...IM swears she isn't an Obama hater and likes to point out OTHER people's partisanship at every turn. She just CAN'T be a partisan Obama hater! LOL. Now where have I pointed out other people's partisanship at every turn? And you, in your sarcasm, are spot on. I don't hate Obama ... hope he is fully successful in quite a number of his agenda items ... private accounts to supplement social security, Afghanistan, a systematic drawdown in Iraq, eliminating wasteful spending, and the list goes on. What I do hate is his seeming abdication of much of his agenda to Congressional scribes ... who I believe have eroded his high ground. You may disagree ... but you ought to be able to do it without engaging in ad hominems. I suppose Axelrod is a "hater" too ... quote: White House aides said they debated whether the president should sign an omnibus spending bill that includes more than 8,500 pet projects worth $7.7 billion. White House counselor David Axelrod suggested a veto would send a strong signal that Mr. Obama's Washington really would represent change. But the president decided it wasn't worth adding a fight with his own party onto a plate that is already overly filled.
quote: Originally posted by SeaWitch1220: quote: Originally posted by jrnh5150: Perhaps the Obama haters overlooked something? No, can't be...IM swears she isn't an Obama hater and likes to point out OTHER people's partisanship at every turn. She just CAN'T be a partisan Obama hater!

I don't hate Obama ... hope he is fully successful in quite a number of his agenda items ... private accounts to supplement social security, Afghanistan, a systematic drawdown in Iraq, eliminating wasteful spending, and the list goes on. What I do hate is his seeming abdication of much of his agenda to Congressional scribes ... who I believe have eroded his high ground. You may disagree ... but you ought to be able to do it without engaging in ad hominems. I suppose Axelrod is a "hater" too ... quote: White House aides said they debated whether the president should sign an omnibus spending bill that includes more than 8,500 pet projects worth $7.7 billion. White House counselor David Axelrod suggested a veto would send a strong signal that Mr. Obama's Washington really would represent change. But the president decided it wasn't worth adding a fight with his own party onto a plate that is already overly filled.

At the same time, after Democrats criticized former President George W. Bush's signing statements, Mr. Obama issued one of his own, declaring five provisions in the spending bill to be unconstitutional and nonbinding, including one aimed at preventing punishment of whistleblowers. <more> "http://online.wsj.com/article/SB123680763049200481.html" Why didn't he veto the bill if it contained 5 unconstitutional provisions ... not to mention all that pork? If President Obama had vetoed the omnibus spending bill – that has been negotiated by both parties since last October, and includes almost 4,000 Republican earmarks - it would tie up Congress for months. Negotiating a new spending bill would take away from the actions needed to address the financial crisis that faces America today. It is a bad bill, but revisiting old business will not move the country forward. President Obama’s real test will come with the next budget, due before October 2009. If you joined John McCain to protest against the out of control spending of the Republican majority Congress in the 2004 budget - and the lack of veto by the Republican president, then ***** away at President Obama, even though he is doing the politically smart thing. If not, you are doing the stupid looking double standard dance. “Ten years ago, in 1994, Republicans won control of both Houses of Congress. For one brief shining moment, we employed true fiscal restraint and eventually managed to balance the budget and even attain that which had seemed unattainable–a surplus! Now, at a time of national crisis, we have thrown caution to the wind and continue to spend, and spend, and spend - all the while cutting taxes. The perfect evidence of this is the number of Congressional earmarks found in the 13 annual appropriations bills. In 1994 there were 4,126 earmarks - this year there were 14,040 earmarks . Where are our priorities?” John McCain, May 2005 How many Democratic earmarks are in the bill? Not to say the Republicans didn't pad it, but how much did the democrats? President Obama campaigned against earmarks in bills just like this one. He was going to change the way business is done. The type of change that could be belived in. He didn't do it here. Seems he is now not for doing the "right" thing but doing the "politically smart" thing. Guess staring at reality and not the campaign trail changes ones perspective. Another CBR could have been passed to keep things moving. Negotiating spending bills is part of the legislative and executive barnches job description. It is one of the most important things they do. Changing old business is not the same as revisiting.
